node.title: Interest rates are tipped to rise later this year. So, is it time to fix your home loan?
node.alt: A stressed woman bites a pencil
node.description: While the Reserve Bank may have kept the official cash rate on hold this week, economists are predicting rates to rise before the end of the year.
node.content:
["It's fair to say money has been cheap in recent years, with home owners having access to the lowest fixed rates on record.\u00a0", "And while the Reserve Bank may have kept the official cash rate on hold this week, economists are predicting rates to rise before the end of the year.", "
So, is it time I fixed my home loan rate?
", "It depends.", "The main\u00a0reason people fix their home loans is because if rates rise, they will have already locked in a lower rate.", "And this fixed rate means you have regular, predictable payments.", "It means you can budget for your interest rate costs and know what you're up for (for as long as you locked your rate in, this could be between one to 10 years).", "Right now, the bottom of the market has probably already passed.", "Fixed rates got down to under 2 per cent last year, but they are already on the move, says RateCity's\u00a0director of research, Sally Tindall.", "\"In six months'\u00a0time, the majority of owner-occupied fixed rates are likely to start with a '3',\u00a0while investors could even be looking at some rates that start with a '4',\" she says.\u00a0", "Take a look at this table. It shows the increases in rates on a two-year fixed rate from each of the big four banks (in 2021 and today).", "The three-year fixed rates have gone up even more \u2014\u00a0by about 1 per cent!", "But of course, rates could rise\u00a0even further.\u00a0\u00a0", "And here are the variable rates,\u00a0which have actually gone down since last year.\u00a0", "Note: rates are for owner-occupiers paying principal and interest. Some LVR requirements apply. Westpac\u2019s variable rate in February 2021 was an introductory rate for 2 years.\u00a0Source: RateCity.com.au.", "\"While we expect plenty of these to stick around in the short term, we could see some lenders start to hike variable rates in the second half of this year,\"\u00a0Ms Tindall says.\u00a0", "But don't panic, says Griffith University finance lecturer Di Johnson.\u00a0\u00a0", "\"There are still some great fixed rate deals around compared to pre-COVID, as well as low variable rates,\" she says.", "So it's probably time to ask yourself some questions about your loan and your own financial situation.", "
Can you afford it if rates go up?
", "\"It's helpful to try not to 'time the market'\u00a0but rather to think about what your plans and goals are for the short-term and longer term,\" Dr\u00a0Johnson says.\u00a0", "\"Look beyond the headline interest rates \u2014 check all of the fees and features as well.\"\u00a0", "Have you borrowed too much? Has your work stability changed or has your income dropped since you first took out your loan?", "It's worth doing a comparison on whether you could still afford to pay your loan if it did go up by, say, 1 per cent (plug in your numbers on this Moneysmart mortgage repayment calculator).", "And that can help you decide whether you need to seriously look at fixing your loan right now.", "
What are the risks\u00a0of fixing my home loan?
", "Fixed loans don't work for everyone.", "Firstly, by fixing your loan, you're taking a gamble.", "Interest rates could of course go lower and you're stuck paying a higher rate.", "The loan is also fairly inflexible.", "If you decide you want to pay a bit extra on top of your regular payments, you may not be able to.", "And if you want to remortgage, pay off your mortgage early\u00a0or change back to a variable rate, you'll have to pay hefty break fees", "Don't forget, this can also be a problem if you want to sell your house.", "Fixed loans also don't usually have offset accounts, which can be a great way to make your savings work to help you pay less interest.", "And finally, when your loan is up, you often get rolled on to a much higher variable rate.", "
I don't know what to do! Any other options?
", "Well, yes.", "You could always hedge your bets and just lock in a portion of your loan.", "For instance, if you had a $500,000 loan, you could fix half of that. That means if rates go higher, you're only paying the higher rate on $250,000 (and obviously the same if rates go lower).", "You don't even have to fix half \u2014 you can choose what proportion to fix.", "And even if you decide not to fix your loan at all, it could at least be a good time to reassess your current loan.", "Shop around for the best variable rate and consider switching,\u00a0which will help you save money in the meantime.", "DISCLAIMER: This is just general information. If you need individual advice, please see a professional."]
